data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Introduction to East Asia
data.description: An introductory survey of the history and cultures of East Asia with particular reference to China, Japan, and Korea.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Religions of East Asia
data.description: An examination of the leading religious and philosophical ideas that have shaped the cultures and histories of East Asia: China, Korea, and Japan. Folk, Shamanic, Confucian, Daoist, Shinto, and Buddhist traditions are examined.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Japanese Religions
data.description: An examination of religious phenomena in the history of Japan, including their impact on art, literature, philosophy, and politics. Buddhism, Shinto, Confucianism, folk beliefs, new religious movements, and other traditions are explored.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Chinese Religions
data.description: An examination of religious phenomena in the history of China, including their influence on art, literature, philosophy, and politics. Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, folk beliefs, new religious movements, and other traditions will be explored.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Premodern Chinese Literature
data.description: This course is an introductory survey of the main genres of classical and premodern Chinese literature. Individual works are related to the evolution of the literary tradition and its interaction with history, philosophy and politics. Classical and historical writing, poetry, drama, and novels will be introduced.
data.notes: [Note: Instruction will be in English.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: The History of East Asian Communities in Canada
data.description: This course examines the evolution of the Chinese, Japanese, and Korean communities in Canada as well as their significance for Canadian economic, social, and political life in the 19th and 20th centuries.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Study Abroad in East Asia
data.description: An intensive study of the culture and language of an East Asian country. With the guidance of a course director, students complete readings, attend lectures, and visit cultural sites for six weeks or more on location.
data.notes: [Note: There will be interview and information sessions to confirm that a prospective student has the appropriate background for participation in this course. An appropriate first-year East Asian language course is also required.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Religion and Japanese Film
data.description: The course examines how religious beliefs and values in Japan are explored in the medium of film.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: International Relations of East Asia
data.description: This course explores key topics in the international relations of East Asia after World War II. Classes examine literature on major developments of East Asian relations, including the Cold War, East Asian regionalism, and the foreign policies of China, Japan, and Korea.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Politics and Diplomacy of Contemporary Japan
data.description: This course surveys several key topics in the politics and diplomacy of contemporary Japan, particularly in its relations with its Asia-Pacific neighbours. Topics may include the Pacific War and its legacies, the Japan-US security alliance, the Okinawa problem, and Japan-Canada relations.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: The Political Economy of East Asia
data.description: This course explores the rise of the East Asian economy since the end of World War II. The subject is pursued through examining some of the most important aspects of the so-called Asian miracle/model, including the historical background of the Asian miracle, the role of the state in the region's economic development, the relationship between Asian culture and economic development, social development, and East Asia's business system and practice.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Pure Land Buddhism
data.description: An examination of Pure Land Buddhism, including its origins, development and influence in India, China, Korea, Japan, and the West.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Special Topics in East Asian Studies
data.description: This course deals with selected topics in East Asian studies according to the research and/or instructional interests of faculty.
data.notes: [Note: Students wishing to take this course should consult with the advisor for the East Asian Studies Program.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: The History of East Asian Communities in Canada
data.description: This course examines the evolution of the Chinese, Japanese, and Korean communities in Canada as well as their significance for Canadian economic, social, and political life in the 19th and 20th centuries.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Religions of East Asia
data.description: An examination of the leading religious and philosophical ideas that have shaped the cultures and histories of East Asia: China, Korea, and Japan. Folk, Shamanic, Confucian, Daoist, Shinto, and Buddhist traditions are examined.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Japanese Religions
data.description: An examination of religious phenomena in the history of Japan, including their impact on art, literature, philosophy, and politics. Buddhism, Shinto, Confucianism, folk beliefs, new religious movements, and other traditions are explored.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Chinese Religions
data.description: An examination of religious phenomena in the history of China, including their influence on art, literature, philosophy, and politics. Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, folk beliefs, new religious movements, and other traditions will be explored.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Religion and Japanese Film
data.description: The course examines how religious beliefs and values in Japan are explored in the medium of film.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Pure Land Buddhism
data.description: An examination of Pure Land Buddhism, including its origins, development and influence in India, China, Korea, Japan, and the West.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Calligraphy to Conceptual Art: Text as an Image in Islamic and East Asian Visual Arts
data.description: Exploring the history of Islamic and East Asian calligraphic arts and the study of Eastern and Western artists, this course examines multiple ways in which writing and other forms of visible language are incorporated into visual arts. Through studio projects, students explore conceptual approaches to text-based image making.
data.antirequisites: FINE 204 (section 001) taken Winter 2012 or Winter 2014; SI 375R taken Winter 2014

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Modern Chinese Literature (1917 - present day)
data.description: This survey course explores modern Chinese literature beginning from 1917 and the New Culture movement. Selected works and relevant critiques are used to prompt discussion of cultural and literary topics, particularly of changes in Chinese culture and literature from the beginning of the 20th century to the present day.
data.notes: [Note: Instruction will be in English.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Cold War in East Asia
data.description: This course examines the origins, developments, and contemporary implications of the Cold War in East Asia.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Calligraphy to Conceptual Art: Text as an Image in Islamic and East Asian Visual Arts
data.description: Exploring the history of Islamic and East Asian calligraphic arts and the study of Eastern and Western artists, this course examines multiple ways in which writing and other forms of visible language are incorporated into visual arts. Through studio projects, students explore conceptual approaches to text-based image making.
data.antirequisites: FINE 204 (section 001) taken Winter 2012 or Winter 2014; SI 375R taken Winter 2014

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Cold War in East Asia
data.description: This course examines the origins, developments, and contemporary implications of the Cold War in East Asia.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Calligraphy to Conceptual Art: Text as an Image in Islamic and East Asian Visual Arts
data.description: Exploring the history of Islamic and East Asian calligraphic arts and the study of Eastern and Western artists, this course examines multiple ways in which writing and other forms of visible language are incorporated into visual arts. Through studio projects, students explore conceptual approaches to text-based image making.
data.antirequisites: FINE 204 (section 001) taken Winter 2012 or Winter 2014; SI 375R taken Winter 2014

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Special Topics in East Asian Studies
data.description: This course deals with selected topics in East Asian studies.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of five times.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Premodern Chinese Literature
data.description: This course is an introductory survey of the main genres of classical and premodern Chinese literature. Individual works are related to the evolution of the literary tradition and its interaction with history, philosophy and politics. Classical and historical writing, poetry, drama, and novels will be introduced.
data.notes: [Note: Instruction will be in English.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Chinese Foreign Policy since 1949
data.description: This course examines the major elements and evolution of Chinese foreign policy since 1949 and China's external relations in the context of rising Chinese power.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Korean Law and Society
data.description: This course examines the legal system, legal culture, and socio-cultural traditions of the Republic of Korea from a comparative legal perspective.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Introduction to Pre-Modern Japanese Literature
data.description: Students study a selection of works of early Japanese literature from its beginnings to the 17th century and examine a wide variety of genres, including poetry, diaries, military tales, and philosophical tracts composed during that time period.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Introduction to Early Modern Japanese Literature
data.description: A study of a selection of works of Japanese literature from the 17th century to the early 20th century, examining a wide variety of genres in early modern Japan.
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Special Topics in East Asian Studies
data.description: This course deals with selected topics in East Asian studies according to the research and/or instructional interests of faculty.
data.notes: [Note: Students wishing to take this course should consult with the advisor for the East Asian Studies Program.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Modern Chinese Literature (1917 - present day)
data.description: This survey course explores modern Chinese literature beginning from 1917 and the New Culture movement. Selected works and relevant critiques are used to prompt discussion of cultural and literary topics, particularly of changes in Chinese culture and literature from the beginning of the 20th century to the present day.
data.notes: [Note: Instruction will be in English.]

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Business Environment in East Asia
data.description: The course introduces students to the cultural, social, economic, political, and legal environment for business in East Asia. It covers major economies, such as China, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. The course helps students acquire comprehensive understanding of the business environment of this dynamic region.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Buddhism in East Asia Today
data.description: This course examines modern developments in the Buddhism of China, Japan, and Korea. Topics such as war, urbanization, capitalism, colonialism, Christianity, Communism, the Internet, and nostalgia are explored for their impact on Buddhism.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Korean Pop Culture
data.description: This course explores elements of popular culture such as film, music, television, and video games in relation to social, cultural, and political developments in contemporary South Korea. Students critically analyze readings and non-print media to consider South Korean popular culture in national, regional, and global contexts.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Global Asian Diasporas
data.description: This course explores the literature and culture from one or more global Asian diasporas, with particular emphasis on cultures of East Asian origin. Topics may include identity, transnationalism, imperialism, war, labour, migration, and popular culture.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Global Asian Diasporas
data.description: This course explores the literature and culture from one or more global Asian diasporas, with particular emphasis on cultures of East Asian origin. Topics may include identity, transnationalism, imperialism, war, labour, migration, and popular culture.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Chinese Foreign Policy since 1949
data.description: This course examines the major elements and evolution of Chinese foreign policy since 1949 and China's external relations in the context of rising Chinese power.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Buddhism in East Asia Today
data.description: This course examines modern developments in the Buddhism of China, Japan, and Korea. Topics such as war, urbanization, capitalism, colonialism, Christianity, Communism, the Internet, and nostalgia are explored for their impact on Buddhism.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Introduction to East Asia
data.description: An introductory survey of the history and cultures of East Asia with particular reference to China, Japan, and Korea.

data.subject: EASIA
data.title: Introduction to Modern China
data.description: This is an introductory survey course on China as a modern nation-state. The course provides a broad overview of the country by looking at major aspects of modern China, including the trajectory of China's rise since the 1980s.
